I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Second Small and Microfinance Development Project. The 
report also describes a technical assistance (TA) proposal for Capacity Building for Microfinance 
Development,  and  if  the  Board  approves  the  proposed  loan,  I,  acting  under  the  authority 
delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
2.  The Project facilitates access to credit by micro and small enterprises (MSEs) across 
Uzbekistan. It supports the generation of employment and sustains about 30,000 jobs for men 
and  women.  It  contributes  to  inclusive  economic  growth.  ADB’s  proposed  intervention 
comprises (i) a loan of $50 million to be channeled through three participating commercial banks 
(PCBs)1 for onlending to viable MSEs; and (ii) a TA grant of $600,000 to improve PCBs' MSE  
finance  capacity  and  their  subborrowers'  entrepreneurial  skills.  Appendix  1  contains  the 
project’s design and monitoring framework.   
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Economic  significance  of  small  business. After a difficult transition in the 1990s 
following the collapse of the Soviet Union, Uzbekistan’s economy has been growing steadily. 
Between 2005 and 2009, the average rate of increase in gross domestic product (GDP) was 
8.2%.  The share of small businesses in the GDP increased from 30% in 2000 to 50% in 2009. 
This is expected to increase to 52.5% in 2010. By the end of 2009, there were about 8.4 million 
people working in 422,401 MSEs and sole proprietorship businesses.2 A focus on horticulture3 
and  value-added  processing,  storage,  transport,  and  other  related  services  in  the  farm-to-
market  chain  benefits  microenterprises  (i.e.,  smallholder  farms  and  plantations)  and  small 
businesses (storage, refrigeration, transport services, wholesale, retail, and agro-processing). 
There  are  strong  complementarities  between  these  two  business  segments  because  of 
backward and forward linkages.4   
 
4.  Unmet credit demand. Despite strong credit growth in recent years, demand by MSEs 
remains unmet at present. According to the Central Bank of Uzbekistan, total loans granted by 
commercial banks to MSEs reached $898 million (SUM1.25 trillion) in 2008 and $1.2 billion 
(SUM1.85 trillion) in 2009. The amount allocated to microcredit by commercial banks increased 
by about 100% in 2009 over 2008 and is targeted to increase by another 30% to reach $275 
million (SUM 420 billion) in 2010.5 According to a World Bank survey,6 only 7.8% of business 
financing is met by loans—the lowest percentage in the region (where the average is 23.3%). 
                                                 
1  The PCBs are Agrobank, Hamkorbank, and Ipak Yuli Bank.   
2  In Uzbekistan, a microenterprise is defined as an enterprise employing 1–20 persons in industry and 1–5 (in some 
cases 1–10) persons in services; a small enterprise is one that employs 21–50 persons in agriculture and industry, 
and 6–25 persons in services (Resolution of the Cabinet of Minister of the Republic of Uzbekistan, no. 439, dated 
11 October 2003). At the end of 2008, small enterprises employed 525,500 persons and microenterprises 
employed  about  1.64  million  persons;  another  5.86  million  were  self-employed,  running  sole  proprietorship 
businesses. 
3  Agricultural reforms have freed horticulture from state quotas and price controls and, particularly in the Fergana 
Valley, encouraged family farms to concentrate on horticulture. 
4  Macroeconomic and Sector Analysis, and Country Economic Indicators (Appendix 2). 
5  The Law on Microfinance, approved in September 2006, quantifies microcredit as 1,000 times the minimum wage 
(presently pegged at SUM37,800), microloans as 100 times the minimum wage, and micro-leasing as 2,000 times 
the minimum wage.  
6  World Bank Group. 2009. Enterprise Surveys. Country Note. Uzbekistan.

2     
ADB’s past credit lines to Uzbekistan7 indicate high demand from micro, small, and medium-
sized business operating in all sectors, particularly agriculture and agroprocessing. 
 
5.  Underdeveloped  and  regulated  financial  sector.  MSE’s  access  to  credit  is 
constrained by the nature and characteristics of the financial sector in Uzbekistan, which is 
subject to various distortions. For instance, directed lending at subsidized interest rates leads to 
misallocation of resources. For depositors, practical difficulties in cash withdrawals from bank 
accounts have created a premium for cash and a trust gap for banks in terms of their ability to 
mobilize customer deposits. This is manifested by a low (individual and household customer) 
bank deposits–GDP ratio of 6.6% in 2009.8 The government has put in place measures to 
increase  public  confidence  in  the  banking  system  which  are  expected  to  raise  deposits 
mobilization.9 
 
6.  Selection of strong PCBs. The proposed intervention will meet a share of the MSE 
credit  demand  while  addressing  financial  sector  distortions.  This  will  be  achieved  through 
working with PCBs committed to sustainable MSE financing that meet the following criteria: 
(i) financial soundness (solvency, liquidity, profitability, efficiency, and prudence);10 (ii) extensive 
rural retail network; (iii) a proven track record and efficiency in non-subsidized microfinance 
intermediation; (iv) ability and willingness to manage the foreign exchange risk prudently; and 
(v) transparent corporate, financial, and management governance practices. Based on these 
criteria,  ADB  selected  three  PCBs:  Agrobank,  Hamkorbank,  and  Ipak  Yuli  Bank  (IYB). 
Hamkorbank and IYB are privately owned, while Agrobank is majority government owned.  
 
7.  The  selected  PCBs’  business  models  and  client  profile  correspond  well  with  the 
proposed project objectives. Their business models aim at (i) increasing their retail presence 
geographically, (ii) diversifying operations into various sectors, (iii) offering new products to 
meet customer needs and increase profitability, and (iv) better outreach to viable but unbanked 
and  under-banked  potential  clients.  Their  client  base  is  diverse:  Agrobank  has  a  strong 
presence in the agriculture and agro-processing sectors, while Hamkorbank and IYB are more 
focused in the trade finance sector (IYB also has significant exposure to light manufacturing). 
Micro and small business loans constitute close to one-third of Hamkorbank’s and one-fourth of 
IYB’s loan portfolios; for Agrobank, they constitute one-tenth (given the much larger size of its 
overall portfolio). For their loans up to $20,000, the average loan size is $4,000, with an average 
repayment period of 18 months. These loans finance both investment and working capital.  
 
                                                 
7  ADB. 1996. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan and Technical 
Assistance Grant to the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Rural Enterprise Development Project. Manila (Loan 1504-
UZB, $50 million, approved on 17 December); ADB. 2000. Report and Recommendation of the President to the 
Board  of  Directors:  Proposed  Loan  to  the  Republic  of  Uzbekistan  for  the  Small  and  Medium  Enterprise 
Development Project. Manila (Loan 1799-UZB, $50 million, approved on 11 December); and ADB. 2002. Report 
and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan and Technical Assistance Grant 
to the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Small and Microfinance Development Project. Manila (Loan 1963-UZB, $20 
million, approved on 9 December). 
8  Source: Central Bank of Uzbekistan.  
9  These measures, complemented by the banks’ own deposit mobilization effort, have shown some success. The 
individual and household bank deposits–GDP ratio increased consistently since 2000, from 0.9% to 6.6% in 2009 
(or from SUM33.6 billion to SUM2.9 trillion in 2009, in absolute terms). For further details, see Macroeconomic and 
Sectoral Analysis, and Country Economic Indicators (Appendix 2). 
10 For solvency, PCBs will be required to have a Basel I compliant capital adequacy ratio of not less than 12%. For 
profitability, they will have a return on assets ratio of not less than 1%. For liquidity, they will maintain a loan–
deposit ratio of under 100%. For efficiency, they will be required to have an intermediation cost ratio of less than 
15%. To be conservative and financially prudent, the PCBs’ loan delinquency and write-off ratio shall not exceed 
5%.

3
8.  ADB loan size linked to PCB’s business growth. Judging by their loan–deposit ratios, 
all three PCBs have demonstrated an ability to raise and retain customer deposits for MSE 
intermediation. Their outstanding MSE loan balances were $51.4 million in December 2008 and 
$75.8 million in November 2009, i.e. growing by more than 50% notwithstanding the global 
financial crisis. Assuming a similar linear trajectory on a compounded basis, their MSE loans 
outstanding could reach $484.6 million by 2013. The expected credit growth justifies an ADB 
loan of $50 million, which complements but does not substitute the PCBs’ deposit mobilization. 
To demonstrate their commitment to the MSE sector, PCBs will be required to match ADB’s 
credit allocation with their own funds. 
 
9.  Market orientation and increase in financial choices. The Government has agreed 
with  the  application  of  market-based  principles  under  the  project,  including  market  based 
onlending rates, choice of currency by sub-borrowers and unrestricted cash withdrawals for sum 
subloans. PCBs may offer US dollar subloans through bank transfers. In the case of subloans in 
sum, subborrowers may draw down loans in any legal form, including cash. This effectively 
addresses the existing distortion between cash and noncash markets.11 Collateral will be neither 
a condition nor a prohibition. Given the continuous depreciation of the sum against the US 
dollar, it is expected that MSEs will borrow in US dollars only if their revenues are denominated 
in hard currency. This may be the case mainly for MSEs engaged in trading. Given the profile of 
their clients, the volume of US dollar denominated subloans is expected to be higher in the case 
of Hamkorbank and IYB12 than Agrobank.13 
 
10.  Attention to underserviced groups and gender sensitivity. To benefit subborrowers 
of smaller subloans, PCBs may make subloans to microcredit organizations (MCOs) up to 
$20,000 equivalent each, provided they (i) apply the subloan eligibility criteria to subborrowers; 
and (ii) make loans to their (MCOs) subborrowers not exceeding $1,000 each. This approach 
will give PCBs the advantage of wholesale economies by lending to institutions that target lower 
income  beneficiaries,  particularly  among  women.  To  ensure  wide  distribution,  50%  of  the 
aggregate outstanding principal amounts of PCBs lending under the project to subborrowers 
other than MCOs will be for loan sizes up to $10,000. Lending by the three PCBs to women 
currently represents one-quarter to one-third of the total number of microcredit loans. TA will be 
provided to help improve the PCBs’ credit appraisal capacities for MSE and gender sensitivity, 
as  well  as  to  improve  the  skills  of  subborrowers  (particularly  women)  in  business  plan 
preparation  and  credit  application.  This  will  complement  credit  outreach  and  client 
empowerment work. 
 
11.  Strategic fit and lessons learned. The project complies with ADB’s country partnership 
strategy, 14 which  supports  sustainable  economic  growth,  poverty  reduction,  gender  and 
development, and its Microfinance Strategy.15 For rural nonfarm enterprise development, ADB’s 
country partnership strategy encourages forward and backward linkages with the agricultural 
sector.  These  linkages  absorb surplus  labor  released  from  agriculture.  The  loan  will carry 
forward this principle to other sectors as well. It also supports the development of rural financial 
services and promotes more efficient intermediation functions by commercial banks. It seeks (by 
allowing subborrowers to draw down their sum subloans in cash if they so choose) to abolish 
                                                 
11 The principle of withdrawal of sum subloans in cash is consistent with the law in Uzbekistan, and has been 
followed in a similar project financed by another multilateral agency.   
12 At the end of 2008, the share of US dollar-denominated assets was 29.5% in Hamkorbank’s balance sheet and 
16.6% in IYB’s balance sheet.  
13 Macroeconomic and Sectoral Analysis (Appendix 2). 
14 ADB. 2006. Country Strategy and Program: Uzbekistan, 2006–2010. Manila. 
15 ADB. 2000. Finance for the Poor: Microfinance Development Strategy. Manila.

4     
the distinction between cash and noncash market transactions. The project was designed after 
consultation with stakeholders, including other development partners, and incorporates lessons 
learned from previous ADB microfinance interventions.16 In an earlier loan, ADB underestimated 
the  demand  for  micro  and  small  business  credit  and  selected  a  bank  with  only  limited 
experience in micro and small business lending. This time, ADB has selected PCBs with proven 
operational and financial capacity for MSE credit delivery and assessed the demand for credit 
based on the business projections of the PCBs.  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The project will generate jobs and create business opportunities in the MSE sector, thus 
contributing  to  welfare  improvement  in  Uzbekistan  (Appendix  1).  Its  outcome  will  be  an 
expanded, viable and sustainable MSE finance sector, and thus an increase of investment 
opportunities. 17 
 
C.  Outputs 
13.  The project will expand microfinance delivery to financially viable subborrowers (men 
and women), by providing funding and training to the three PCBs. The project will also improve 
the entrepreneurial capacity of subborrowers, especially women, by training them in business 
plan preparation and credit applications. 
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans 
 
14.  ADB will provide a loan of $50 million. PCBs will provide $50 million in counterpart 
funding.18  
 
E.  Lending, Relending, and Onlending Arrangements 
 
15.  The  government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $50  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources. The loan will have a 20-year term including a grace period of 5 years, an annual 
interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-
based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per year, and other such terms and 
conditions included in the loan and project agreements. The government has provided ADB with 
(i) the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility based on 
these terms and conditions, and (ii) an undertaking that these choices were its own independent 
decision and not made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. 
 
16.  The Republic of Uzbekistan will be the borrower. The government will relend to the 
PCBs the loan proceeds through three subsidiary loan agreements (SLAs):19 up to $20 million 
for Hamkorbank, up to $20 million for Agrobank, and up to $10 million for IYB. If there is any 
change  to  the  current  composition  of  PCBs,  the  borrower  may  reallocate  loan  proceeds 
between the PCBs in a manner acceptable to ADB. The government may charge the PCBs an 
                                                 
16 Development Coordination (Appendix 2). 
17 Contribution to the Output Aggregates of the ADB Results Framework and Project Classification Summary 
(Appendix 2). 
18 For each subproject financed by a PCB, at least 30% of the subproject costs shall be met by equity contribution 
from the subborrower. The balance of the subproject costs shall be financed via a subloan from the PCB. Such 
subloan shall comprise 50% from the PCB’s funds and 50% from the proceeds of the ADB loan relent to the PCB. 
19 It is expected that under SLAs: (i) the term of government relending to PCBs will be for 15 years, with a 3-year 
grace period; (ii) a margin of up to 0.5%; and (iii) commitment fees charged to PCBs on a pro rata basis. The PCBs 
have until 31 December 2013 to avail of their drawdown.

5
appropriate margin for assuming the risk of loss due to the possibility of PCBs' nonpayment of 
the loan. The PCBs will onlend loan funds in either sum or in US dollars to their subborrowers at 
market interest rates for up to 3 years. This will enable recycling of loan funds and thus widen 
the number of beneficiaries. Subloans may be either to new or repeat subborrowers as long as 
they meet viability standards.20 The PCBs will manage their foreign exchange and credit risks 
prudently by charging appropriate risk premiums, which will be factored into their onlending 
rates for subloans.21 
 
F.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will be the executing agency for the project and be 
responsible for drafting, executing, and overseeing the SLAs with the PCBs. The three PCBs 
will be the implementing agencies for their activities in the project. ADB will enter into a loan 
agreement with MOF and three separate project agreements with the PCBs.22 Each PCB will 
establish a project implementation unit adequately staffed and acceptable to ADB, as defined in 
the project administration manual (PAM), discussed and agreed with the government and the 
PCBs.23 The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1 and described in detail in 
the PAM.

III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
19.  ADB’s capacity development TA will (i) train banks on MSE credit appraisal customized 
to ADB's requirements, (ii) sensitize PCB staff on the need for increasing MSE loans to women, 
(iii) educate women borrowers on business plan preparation and credit application, (iv) sensitize

their track records, future cash flows, third-party guarantees, existing debt obligations, and other criteria deemed

their display of MSE loan procedures on their websites and train their staff in microfinance

The three PCBs will finance the balance in kind. MOF will be the executing agency for the TA. 
The three PCBs will be the implementing agencies for the TA. 
 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
20.  ADB’s  initial  due  diligence  indicates  that  this  credit  facilty  is  financially  viable, 
economically sustainable, socially desirable, and legally permissible. 
 
A.  Economic and Financial 
21.  The three PCBs’ track records (by review of their audited financial statements, internal 
control procedures, and corporate and financial governance practices) show them to be solvent, 
profitable, liquid, efficient, and conservative. Their past capital adequacy ratios have been equal 
to or higher than 12%, according to Basel I formulations. Their return on assets have been 
equal  to  or  higher  than  1%.  Their  loan–deposit  ratios  have  been  under  100%,  their 
intermediation cost ratios under 15%, and their bad debts have never exceeded 5%.25 The 
PCBs will be required to maintain such sound financial performance ratios in the future while 
implementing  the  loan,  to  continue  to  be  eligible  intermediaries.26 The  subproject  eligibility 
criteria are designed to ensure viability and continued operational and financial soundness. 
 
22.  Sustainability will be supported by the government and Central Bank of Uzbekistan, by 
(i) allowing PCBs to onlend ADB funds at market interest rates without restrictions on the type or 
purpose of loan fund use; (ii) permitting subborrowers to draw down sum subloans in any legal 
form,  including  cash;  (iii)  creating  the  necessary  enabling  macroeconomic  and  financial 
environment from the legal, regulatory, and policy perspective for MSE development; and (iv) 
providing ADB with information necessary to monitor ADB’s results framework. 
 
B.  Governance 
23.  Reviews were conducted for the PCBs’ credit, operational, and counterparty risks. ADB 
is satisfied with measures for monitoring and mitigating these risks. The three PCBs' financial 
statements are prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards and 
audited  by  internationally  recognized  external  auditors  in  accordance  with  International 
Standards of Auditing acceptable to ADB. The three PCBs' corporate and financial governance 
standards fully meet ADB's requirements. ADB will work closely with the government and PCBs 
to  ensure  that  subloans  will  not  finance  activities  that  contradict  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement.  A  PAM  outlining  the  detailed  project  implementation  arrangement  and  ADB’s 
financial management assessment, agreed between ADB, the government, and PCBs, will be 
adhered to throughout the implementation period.

C.  Poverty and Social 
25.  Despite Uzbekistan’s recent economic growth, 25.8% of its households are below the 
poverty line.27 Poverty is correlated with unemployment or underemployment.28 Since MSEs are 
labor–intensive, they can provide employment and empowerment opportunities to the poor. 
Bank credit is an important prerequisite to this goal. Even if PCBs’ subborrowers are not 
themselves poor, their use of bank credit will enable them to hire 30,000 more workers (both 
men and women) between 2010 and 2013.29 This will raise employment and indirectly reduce 
poverty.30 Providing jobs domestically will reduce outward migration (of the unemployed) and 
mitigate social costs. 
 
26.  Thus far, only about 22% of total bank lending in Uzbekistan has gone to women.31 This 
loan is expected to raise their share through (i) training of women borrowers; (ii) sensitization of 
bank staff; (iii) developing types of lending of particular interest to women such as solidarity 
group lending, micro-leasing, and lending against the future flow of remittances (to wives of 
migrant workers); (iv) introduction of life and accident credit insurance products to micro-loan 
borrowers; and (v) lending to MCOs, which will benefit poor women particularly in remote rural 
areas. The PCBs will maintain sex-disaggregated data on the beneficiaries of their small and 
microfinance loans and will report such information to ADB. The project has effective gender 
mainstreaming content.32 
 
D.  Safeguards 
27.  The Project conforms to ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement33 and complies with the 
requirements  of  Uzbekistan’s  labor,  environmental,  health,  safety,  and  social  laws  and 
regulations. It falls under the Financial Intermediary (FI) category with respect to environment 
and social safeguards. It is treated as category C, as PCBs will finance only those subprojects 
which have minimal or no adverse social or environmental risks. Any subprojects (i) falling 
under  ADB’s  environmental  and  social  safeguard  categories  A  and  B,  and/or  (ii) which 
specifically  require  environmental  assessment  clearances  by  the  government,  will  not  be 
financed under the loan. ADB’s prohibited investment activity list will apply. 
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
28.  This operation is classified as low risk, considering (i) the loan amount is only $50 
million; (ii) the sound record of ADB’s previous experience in the sector; and (iii) reasonable 
executing agency capacity. This loan is categorized environment category FI, but treated as C
